systemPipeShiny 0.99.0

SPS terminal message logging methods

Source: R/spsUti.R
msg.Rd

If SPS use_crayonoption is TRUE, the message will be colorful. "INFO" level spawns message, "WARNING" is warning, "ERROR" spawns stop, other levels use cat. spsinfo, spswarn, spserror are higher level wrappers of msg. The only difference is they have SPS- prefix.

spsinfo has an additional arg verbose. This arg works similar to all other verbose args in this package, if not specified, it follows the project option, can be be forced to TRUE and FALSE. TRUE will forcefully generate the msg, and FALSE will be no message.

msg(
  msg,
  level = "INFO",
  .other_color = "white",
  info_text = "INFO",
  warning_text = "WARNING",
  error_text = "ERROR"
)

spsinfo(msg, verbose = NULL)

spswarn(msg)

spserror(msg)

Arguments

msg

a character string of message or a vector of character strings, each item in the vector presents one line of words
level

typically, one of "INFO", "WARNING", "ERROR", lower case OK. Other levels ok.
.other_color

hex color code or named colors, when levels are not in "INFO", "WARNING", "ERROR", this value will be used
info_text

info level text prefix
warning_text

warning level text prefix
error_text

error level text prefix
verbose

bool, default get from sps project options, can be overwritten

Value

see description

Details

If you want to use this function to generate colorful log messages but not in SPS framework. Use spsOption to set up the option on very top of your scripts: spsOption("use_crayon", TRUE).

Examples

msg("this is info")

#> [INFO] 2020-09-29 17:09:56 this is info
msg("this is warning", "warning")

#> Warning: 
[WARNING] 2020-09-29 17:09:56 this is warning
try(msg("this is error", "error"))

#> Error : 
[ERROR] 2020-09-29 17:09:56 this is error
msg("this is other", "error2")

#> [error2] 2020-09-29 17:09:56 this is other
spsinfo("some msg, verbose false", verbose = FALSE) # will not show up
spsinfo("some msg, verbose true", verbose = TRUE)

#> [SPS-INFO] 2020-09-29 17:09:56 some msg, verbose true
spswarn("sps warning")

#> Warning: 
[SPS-WARNING] 2020-09-29 17:09:56 sps warning
try(spserror("sps error"))

#> Error : 
[SPS-ERROR] 2020-09-29 17:09:56 sps error
